1983 Tour de France - Index 0: Stage P was held on 1 July, starting from Fontenay-sous-Bois. It was an individual time trial covering a distance of 6 km (3.7 mi), and the winner was Eric Vanderaerden (BEL).
1983 Tour de France - Index 1: Stage 1 took place on 2 July, running from Nogent-sur-Marne to Créteil. This plain stage covered 163 km (101 mi) and was won by Frits Pirard (NED).
1983 Tour de France - Index 5: On 6 July, Stage 5 stretched from Le Havre to Le Mans, a plain stage route covering 257 km (160 mi). The winner was Dominique Gaigne (FRA).
1983 Tour de France - Index 6: Stage 6 occurred on 7 July, featuring an individual time trial from Châteaubriant to Nantes over 58 km (36 mi). The stage winner was Bert Oosterbosch (NED).
1983 Tour de France - Index 7: The 7th stage was on 8 July, from Nantes to Île d'Oléron, covering a distance of 216 km (134 mi) in a plain stage. Riccardo Magrini (ITA) emerged victorious.
1983 Tour de France - Index 8: On 9 July, Stage 8 went from La Rochelle to Bordeaux. This plain stage was 222 km (138 mi) long, with Bert Oosterbosch (NED) winning again.
1983 Tour de France - Index 9: Stage 9 on 10 July led the riders from Bordeaux to Pau over 207 km (129 mi) in another plain stage, won by Philippe Chevallier (FRA).
1983 Tour de France - Index 11: On 12 July, Stage 11 took place between Bagnères-de-Luchon and Fleurance, spanning 177 km (110 mi). Régis Clère (FRA) took the stage win in this plain stage.
1983 Tour de France - Index 12: The following day, Stage 12 covered 261 km (162 mi) from Fleurance to Roquefort-sur-Soulzon, a plain stage won by Kim Andersen (DEN).
1983 Tour de France - Index 14: On 15 July, Stage 14 from Aurillac to Issoire covered 149 km (93 mi). It was a hilly stage, and Pierre Le Bigaut (FRA) was the winner.
1983 Tour de France - Index 15: Stage 15 on 16 July was an individual time trial from Clermont-Ferrand to Puy de Dôme, spanning 16 km (9.9 mi). Ángel Arroyo (ESP) claimed victory.
1983 Tour de France - Index 18: Stage 18 was on 20 July, a mountain stage from Le Bourg-d'Oisans to Morzine over 247 km (153 mi), won by Jacques Michaud (FRA).
1983 Tour de France - Index 21: On 23 July, Stage 21 in Dijon was an individual time trial covering 50 km (31 mi). Laurent Fignon (FRA) was the stage winner.
1983 Tour de France - Index 22: The final stage, Stage 22, occurred on 24 July. It was a plain stage from Alfortville to Paris (Champs-Élysées) spanning 195 km (121 mi), won by Gilbert Glaus (SUI).
